bibl.title: Letter from Joseph Berkson to Henry E. Sigerist, December 18, 1940

div1.p: Berkson writes that he was impressed by Hench's lecture on the yellow fever experiments. He thinks Hench's paper should be published in Johns Hopkins University's "Bulletin of the History of Medicine."

div1.head: Letter from Joseph Berkson to Henry E. Sigerist, December 18, 1940
div1.p:
December 18, 1940 Dr. Henry E. Sigrist
Johns Hopkins University
Institute of the History of Medicine
1900 East Monument Street
Baltimore, Maryland
Dear Dr. Sigrist:

I was thinking of you and your Bulletin the other night when
I listened to a lecture given by Dr. Philip Hench who is head of one of
the medical sections here at the Clinic. He has been interested for
many years in the story of the Reed Yellow Fever Commission and has
been collecting documentary material in connection with it for a long
time.

Last spring, preparatory to a lecture on the subject, he made
a trip to Cuba with the idea of getting some photos and it actually
turned into an archeological and historical expedition of the first
order. Beginning with his suspicion that some ground that had been set
aside for a monument and which was supposed to be the site on which the
famous experiments were performed was not the right place, he was able
to prove the correctness of his doubts, discovered the actual location
with documentary corroboration and purchased the ground himself for a
memorial. Not only this, but he came upon the sensational information
that the supposed accidental infection by a mosquito bite from which
Lazear died was actually an experimental self-inoculation by Lazear,
which he concealed because he thought that if it were known that he
had deliberately infected himself, it would jeopardize his insurance.
The whole story as he tells it is a real thriller.

It occurred to me that you would like to have it for your
Bulletin. I do not know whether this is within the proprieties, but
I might suggest that if you would like to have the article before it
is published elsewhere, that you might write to him and invite him to
submit it. Otherwise it might be published in the local Mayo Clinic
bulletin and thus lose originality for later publication. I think it
would be especially appropriate in your Bulletin since Lazear has a
particular association with Hopkins.

Best regards to you and your family, and good wishes for a
pleasant holiday and a Happy New Year.

Sincerely yours,
Joseph Berkson, M.D.
